intro: Commirhoea, commonly known as the golden mistletoe, is a parasitic plant that grows on the branches of various host trees. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its dense, leafless stems that form a tangled mass. The plant produces small, inconspicuous white flowers followed by red, fleshy berries that are toxic to humans and animals. Commirhoea thrives in temperate climates and is often found in forested areas. Its ecological role includes providing food for certain bird species that disperse its seeds.
